title: If someone wants to write children's books, how would they go about publishing and selling them? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have only done it one way, but that has worked for more than sixty or seventy nonfiction “kids’ books” to half a dozen different publishers to date. Then, it’s up to the publisher (with a little help from the author) to sell the books. To begin, first decide if you want to write fiction or nonfiction. Nonfiction, in my opinion, is easier to sell to a publisher specializing in such works because it usually offers a larger marketplace and, thus, greater sales for the publisher than does fiction. (There are VERY RARE exceptions, of course.) Nonfiction: Decide what age group for which you’re interested in writing—picture books for preschoolers or books for early grades, junior high, or young adult. Then, select an idea that hasn’t already been done to death. Often, you can find fresh ideas in the “adult” news of the day and tailor them to a younger audience. Next, create a fantastic, engaging, one-page maximum pitch or query. Conclude with a few sentences about yourself and why the publisher should contract with you for your book. Find your potential markets (publishers) by checking out children’s book publishers in Writer’s Market or by doing a Google search. Choose the publishers who you think might be the best fit for your book, making sure that those publishers don’t already have books on a similar topic in their catalogs (check out each publisher’s Web page and do a search on Amazon under your book’s topic and the category, “Books,” from Amazon’s drop-down menu.) Finally, e-mail your pitch, with the word “Book Query” or “Book Pitch” followed by the subject matter clearly identified in the e-mail’s subject line (example: “Book Pitch: Ty Cobb—Baseball’s King of Kings”). If you can’t find a submissions e-mail on the publisher’s Web site or from your Web searches, use the publisher’s telephone number and call to ask how to submit a book proposal by e-mail. (Chances are the e-mail address will be something such as “Submissions@PublishersName.com” but check to make sure so you don’t waste time.) If the publisher lists any submissions’ guidelines, be sure to follow them. Nothing upsets an editor more than a writer who can’t follow instructions! Finally, do NOT send a sample of the book (or, God forbid, the entire manuscript!) until asked to do so. Failing to follow this simple rule is guaranteed to get your query a quick trip to the “reject pile.” Fiction: For submitting fiction, it’s doubly important to follow the publisher’s on-site guidelines (or those you find in Writer’s Market or other reliable sources). That’s because no two publishers require the same thing. Some may request a query letter ONLY; others, a query letter and the first few pages of the manuscript; a few others, a query letter and the complete manuscript. Also, some publishers are adamant about copying and pasting your material into the body of the e-mail instead of attaching it to an e-mail. Follow instructions to the letter, and then sit back, wait, and hope for the best. Oh, and if you haven’t heard anything from the publisher in the publisher’s proscribed period of time (often they suggest 2 - 3 months), feel free to follow up after that to make sure your material was received. If, on the other hand, the publisher has a policy of “no response means no interest,” don’t bother following up because you’ll only be wasting your time and that of the editor. Hope this helps.

Good for you for wanted to publish a children’s book. I have self published 6 children’s books for my mother. If you learn nothing else from my post, remember this: Publishers Are Vultures. For three years now since the fist book was published I have received daily email and phone calls from some of the world’s largest publishers. For a small fee ($1500–$10′000) they will assist me with our next book. A publishers can not provide anything than I can do for free. A publisher who buys the rights to your book/books will need to see proof of sales. If you can sell 100′000 books a publisher might look at you next book. Amazon only does Softcover and Ingram does hard & softcover. I know use IngramSpark as they are Print on Demand. They print your book as needed.
